title: David Storl
text:
David Storl (born 27 July 1990) is a German <a href="track%20and%20field">track and field</a> athlete who specialises in the <a href="shot%20put">shot put</a>. He was successful on the youth and junior <a href="athletics%20%28sport%29">athletics</a> circuit, winning <a href="gold%20medal">gold medal</a>s at the <a href="World%20Youth%20Championships%20in%20Athletics">World Youth Championships</a> and <a href="World%20Junior%20Championships%20in%20Athletics">World Junior Championships</a>. Storl won his first senior medal, a silver, at the <a href="2011%20European%20Athletics%20Indoor%20Championships">2011 European Athletics Indoor Championships</a>.
He held the <a href="list%20of%20world%20junior%20records%20in%20athletics">world junior record</a> of 22.73 m with the 6 kg shot. His personal best with the senior implement is 22.20 m.
He won the gold medal in the shot put competition at the <a href="2011%20World%20Championships%20in%20Athletics">2011 World Championships in Athletics</a>, and the Silver Medal at the <a href="2012%20Summer%20Olympics">2012 Summer Olympics</a>.
Storl is one of only nine athletes (along with <a href="Valerie%20Adams">Valerie Adams</a>, <a href="Usain%20Bolt">Usain Bolt</a>, <a href="Veronica%20Campbell-Brown">Veronica Campbell-Brown</a>, <a href="Jacques%20Freitag">Jacques Freitag</a>, <a href="Yelena%20Isinbayeva">Yelena Isinbayeva</a>, <a href="Kirani%20James">Kirani James</a>, <a href="Jana%20Pittman">Jana Pittman</a>, and <a href="Dani%20Samuels">Dani Samuels</a>) to win world championships at the youth, junior, and senior level of an athletic event.
Storl uses the <a href="Shot%20put%23Glide">glide</a> technique for shot putting.
Career.
Storl first became involved in <a href="athletics%20%28sport%29">athletics</a> as a child when his grandfather suggested he join the local club, VfL Rochlitzer Berg. Initially a <a href="decathlon">decathlon</a> specialist, the death of his personal coach in 2006 led him to focus exclusively on the <a href="shot%20put">shot put</a> and <a href="discus%20throw">discus</a> throwing events. At the age of 16, he won the <a href="gold%20medal">gold medal</a> at the <a href="2007%20World%20Youth%20Championships%20in%20Athletics">2007 World Youth Championships</a> with a personal best and German under-18 record throw of 21.40 metres (using the lighter 5 kg shot for youths).
The following year he competed with the 6 kg junior implement and won the shot put title at the <a href="2008%20World%20Junior%20Championships%20in%20Athletics">2008 World Junior Championships in Athletics</a> with a mark of 21.08 m, which made him the fourth-best junior of all time. In 2009, he began using the full senior weight (7.26 kg) in the indoor season and achieved a best of 19.48 m. Returning to the junior 6 kg shot in the outdoor season, he became the first ever junior athlete to throw beyond 22 metres in <a href="Mannheim">Mannheim</a>, setting consecutive <a href="list%20of%20world%20junior%20records%20in%20athletics">world junior records</a> of 22.18 m and then 22.34 m. A month later he increased this mark to 22.73 m in <a href="Osterode%20am%20Harz">Osterode</a> (putting some distance between himself and the <a href="Edis%20Elkasevic">Edis Elkasevic</a>'s former record of 21.96 m), and went on to win the <a href="2009%20European%20Athletics%20Junior%20Championships">2009 European Junior title</a> with a championships record of 22.40 m. Having placed third at the <a href="2009%20German%20Athletics%20Championships">2009 German Athletics Championships</a> and achieved the senior international "A" standard with a personal best throw of 20.43 m, he was selected for the <a href="2009%20World%20Championships%20in%20Athletics">2009 World Championships in Athletics</a> in <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a>. He ended his first senior international appearance in 15th place in the qualifying rounds.
The 2010 season was his first as a senior athlete and he was runner-up at the Indoor and <a href="2010%20German%20Athletics%20Championships">Outdoor German Championships</a>. At the <a href="2010%20IAAF%20World%20Indoor%20Championships">2010 IAAF World Indoor Championships</a>, he came seventh while compatriot <a href="Ralf%20Bartels">Ralf Bartels</a> won the bronze. Storl represented Germany at the <a href="2010%20European%20Athletics%20Championships">2010 European Athletics Championships</a> and managed fourth place. That year he achieved senior personal bests of 20.77 m both outdoors and indoors. He defeated Bartels to win the German indoor title in 2011, but the places were reversed at the <a href="2011%20European%20Athletics%20Indoor%20Championships">2011 European Athletics Indoor Championships</a>, although Storl's <a href="silver%20medal">silver medal</a> was his first major senior medal.
He surpassed the 21-metre mark in Gothenburg in June with a throw of 21.03 m and topped the podium at both the <a href="2011%20European%20Team%20Championships">2011 European Team Championships</a> and <a href="2011%20European%20Athletics%20U23%20Championships">2011 European Athletics U23 Championships</a>, setting championship records of 20.81 m and 20.45 m in the process. With Bartels not competing, Storl won his first outdoor senior national title in July. He added to his best mark with a throw of 21.05 m at the Weltklasse hinterm Deich meeting.
On 12 August 2014, Storl won his second successive European Athletics Championships gold medal with a throw of 21.42m.
Storl surpassed the 22-metre mark on 9 July 2015 in Lausanne with a winning throw of 22.20m, making it his new personal best.
